adverb.description: Moving or appearing to move away from a particular place, especially one that is enclosed or hidden.
examples: he walked out into the street
watch the stars come out

adverb.description: Situated far or at a particular distance from somewhere.
examples: an old farmhouse right out in the middle of nowhere
they lived eight miles out of town
the team had put on a marvelous display out in Georgia
he's gone out

adverb.description: So as to be revealed or known.
examples: find out what you can
the romance fizzled out

adverb.description: (of a light or fire) so as to be extinguished or no longer burning.
examples: at ten o'clock the lights went out

adverb.description: (of a jury) considering its verdict in secrecy.
Indicating a specified distance away from the goal line or finishing line.
examples: he scored from 70 meters out

adverb.description: (of a party, politician, etc.) not in office.

examples: he ran out the door

adjective.description: Not at home or at one's place of work.
examples: if he called, she'd pretend to be out
the secret was soon out
the fire was nearly out
school was out for the summer
a trip to the seaside is out
he was slightly out in his calculations

adjective.description: (of the ball in tennis and similar games) outside the designated playing area.
No longer batting or on base, having had one's turn ended by the team in the field.
examples: the Yankees are out in the ninth
Johnson was out at second

noun.description: A way of escaping from a problem or dilemma.
examples: he was desperately looking for an out

noun.description: An act of putting a player out.
The political party or politicians not in office.

verb.description: Reveal the sexual or gender identity of (a person).

examples: they had outed Asquith quite easily
out the lamp when you're ready
the truth will out

phrases: on the outs with established political trends
Aunt Celia has kicked me out again, for being rebellious and I've been at outs with my uncle for the last 5 years or so.
But now it's foreclosure time: The show is on the outs with me.
Both were examples of buyers who bit off more than they could chew and were on the outs after less than 2 years with their combined companies.
Honey, just because we're on the outs, there's no need to bring the child into it.
origin: Old English ūt (adverb), ūtian (verb), of Germanic origin; related to Dutch uit and German aus.
